children.value: An Overview of Space Opera
Space Opera

is a game in which groups of 6 - 8 players come together to form Societies, and to tell the story of how those Societies address an oncoming existential crisis over the course of multiple generations.
Players have three primary goals in Space Opera:
Overall goal:
Tell an engaging and dramatic story about how people and societies move through existential crisis in collaboration with the other players and artists.
Societal Phase Goal:
Tell the story of how your Society takes action to address the oncoming existential threat.
Individual Phase Goal:
Tell the story of your character for the current generation and their relationship to their society and community.
Each play session of Space Opera is called a Generation. Each Generation consists of multiple rounds. Each round of Space Opera has either three or four phases
Phase 1.  The Universe Responds (2 min)
- During the Universe Responds, the Game Master and Performers drive the conflict forward and bring the world of the game to life in response to the actions the players have taken.
Phase 2. The Societal Phase (15-10 min) -
During the Societal Phase, players work in teams to decide how their society will address the oncoming existential threat.
Phase 3. The Galactic Phase (15-12 min) -
During the Galactic Phase, the Game Master works with players to resolve the actions that their Societies take.
A round of gameplay is one cycle of the above three phases. After every two rounds, players enter the Individual Phase:
Phase 4. The Individual Phase (12 min)
- During the Individual Phase, players narrate the story of their individual characters, and take actions that can impact the Societal Phase.
At the end of a session of play, the Individual Phase is replaced by The Generation Shifts.
Here’s what this pattern looks like:
Round 1
Universe Responds
Societal Phase
Galactic Phase
Round 2
Universe Responds
Societal Phase
Galactic Phase
Individual Phase
Round 3
Universe Responds
Societal Phase
Galactic Phase
Final Round
Universe Responds
Societal Phase
Galactic Phase
Generation Shifts
A Round of Space Opera
The Societal Phase
In the Societal Phase players have
roughly 10 to 15 minutes
to work in their Societies to decide on the actions that their Society will attempt to take this round.
Communities and Voices

During the Societal Phase, each player represents a Community that is part of their Society. These are not the only communities or groups of people that exist within the society, but are the communities who hold a notable or prominent role in the Society at the time. Each community is either a Voice of the People or a Voice of the Leaders.
Voice of the Leaders:
The
decision-makers

. They have direct or indirect control over the levers of power. Communities that are Voice of the Leader vote on societal actions, ambassadors, emissaries, etc, and may or may not consult or consider the opinions of Voice of the People communities in their decision-making.
Voice of the People:
The common folk. Communities that are Voice of the People may voice their opinions or make recommendations during the Societal Phase, but they may not vote.
If there are no Voice of the Leaders in a Society, your society has fallen into a
Crisis of Leadership
Crisis of Leadership

If there are no Voice of the Leaders at your table, your society is in a Crisis of Leadership and as soon as possible during the Societal Phase must resolve that crisis before being able to take an action. To resolve this, every community interested in becoming a Voice of the Leader will roll a dice pool equal to the number of resources they hold. Any communities that roll a 6 become Voice of the Leaders. If no community rolls a 6, all communities that rolled then roll again until at least one community rolls a 6.

Certain cards and actions may trigger a Crisis of Leadership even when there are Voice of the Leaders present. In this case, all Leaders roll first as above to maintain power; If no Leaders roll a 6, then all communities may roll as above.
Once the Crisis of Leadership has been resolved, play continues as normal.
Resources

All communities control resources. Resources represent a significant cultural or material contribution of the Community to the overall society. Resources also measure a Community’s overall health and their cultural influence.

For example, the Community that controls the most resources in a Society may be the largest in terms of population or the most culturally dominant. When people think of this Society they might imagine people who hold this Community’s cultural identity.
On the other hand, a Community with few resources may be considered to be a cultural minority, or their lifeways are at risk of being lost. If a Community
enters the Individual phase with no resources
, that community is Lost, their culture is transformed or forgotten, and the player will need to create a new Community.

In gameplay, resources are used to take actions. When used in an action, resources may be destroyed or transformed. In some cases, additional resources may be created. All resources are mechanically equivalent; however, each resource tells a different story about how the Society approaches the current crisis.
Naming Resources

Resources consist of an adjective and a noun: for example, “Powerful River” or “Industrious Pipefitters.” A good resource is something specific, material, and practical. A bad resource is abstract, like a value, belief, concept, or idea. A bad resource can often become a good resource by describing how it is manifested in the world. For instance, “Charity” is a bad resource because anyone can be charitable, but “Religious Tithing,” “Volunteer Corp,” or “Soup Kitchens” would be good resources.
Taking Actions
How do we take an Action?
We use what we have to do what we can.
To take an action, a society must complete the following phrase
: “We use [resource] to [take action].”
For example:
We use [Merciless Raiders] to [attack the village]
We use [Galactic Maps] to [Discover a land rich in natural resources].
We use [Divine Connection] to [Pray for guidance].

A society can choose to use additional resources to aid the action, increasing the likelihood of success at the cost of risking additional resources. To do this the society must complete this phrase for each additional resource: “We use [additional resource] to [aid action].” The additional resource and the way it is used must make sense with the primary action and be directly connected. If it does not make sense, the society will be more likely to fail its action, or if it is an entirely separate action, the GM may simply remove those resources from the action for this turn.
So if the Raiders of Zoth use their [Merciless Raiders] to [attack the village]...
A good aiding action might be:
We use [Laser Guns] to [arm the Raiders].
And a bad aiding action might be:
We use [Lavish Feasts] to [stuff the enemy’s bellies] — This doesn’t make narrative sense.
We use [Public Relations] to [make it look like we were the good guys] — This is a second action of its own.
A community’s resources cannot be used for an action without their
affirmative
consent.

Finally, each resource that is used is “exhausted,” and cannot be used for any purpose during the next round of gameplay. If your society’s resources are all exhausted, this leaves you defenseless and without the ability to take actions for a full round.
The Flow of the Societal Phase and Deciding Actions
The Societal Phase is divided into four steps: Establish Roles, Propose Actions, Formal Voting, and Joining the Galactic Council
Establish Roles
(suggested that this step takes no longer than 2-minutes)
Confirm which Communities are currently Voice of the Leaders
This is also a good opportunity for the Voice of the Leaders to vote in or vote out Voice of the Leaders.
If there are no decision-makers, your society falls into a
Crisis of Leadership
and must resolve it before moving on.
Select an Emissary.
An Emissary must be one player from a Voice of the Leaders community, and is decided by a majority vote of the current Voice of the Leaders.

Emissaries announce the action that their Society is taking and make any decisions prompted by the GM on behalf of their society, without speaking to the other members of their Society. The Emissary maintains this role until the beginning of the next Societal phase.
Example decisions the Emissary might make include:
Which Communities receive a resource granted on a successful roll.
Which resources are impacted on failed rolls.
Clarifying or adding detail to the action being taken, or what a resource is.
Send Ambassadors or Receive Ambassadors.
This is also a good moment (though not the only moment) for Societies to decide if they would like to send an Ambassador (see below)
Propose Actions
During this step all Communities in the Society can participate in discussion to create and amend proposed actions that the Society might take this round.
A single action must be written down on the Vision Board before moving to the Formal Voting step.
Formal Voting

Only Voice of the Leader communities are able to vote in the final decision as to what the society’s action will be, and in order to pass, it requires a majority vote from the Voice of the Leaders. If a majority vote is not reached, or a vote does not happen the Society takes no action that round. For example:
If there is only one Voice of the Leaders, that player makes the decision on their own.
If there are two Voice of the Leaders, they must both vote for the same action.
If there are three Voice of the Leader, two of the three must both vote for the same action. And so on.
If the vote fails, return to Propose Actions.
Join the Galactic Council

Once a course of action has passed a vote, the Emissary should take their place at the dais for the Galactic Phase. Actions will be heard at the Galactic Council in the order in which the emissaries reach the dais.
At any point during the Societal Phase:
Any Community may
exchange Resources and Willpower.
Two communities can exchange any number of resources or willpower cards (including zero) between one another. This exchange does not need to be equal.
Any Community may
play Willpower Cards.
This may mean that roles established at the beginning of the phase can be disrupted by players with ulterior motives!
Voice of the Leaders may
add new Voice of the Leaders or remove Voice of the Leaders
demoting them to Voice of the People. This process can only be done for one candidate at a time, and requires a majority vote from the current Voice of the Leaders, including any being voted on.
A Society may
send Ambassadors or receive Ambassadors.

Societies may send one or multiple ambassadors to other societies. An Ambassador can be a Voice of the People or a Voice of the Leaders and is decided by a majority vote of the current Voice of the Leaders. The Ambassador takes all of their Resources and Willpower cards with them.

The Voice of the Leaders of the receiving Society must take a majority vote to admit or deny the ambassador, with minimal conversation between the receiving Society and the Ambassador (as to not negate the purpose of sending the Ambassador).
Ex. A potential Ambassador could say, “I am here to discuss trading resources” but cannot give their entire pitch before being accepted.

If an Ambassador is accepted by the other Society they must remain there until the conclusion of the Galactic Phase, and act as a Voice of the People of the receiving Society until they leave. This allows them to use Resources and Willpower cards as usual. Once they have left their home Society, ambassadors may take no part in their home Society until they return. If an Ambassador is rejected they must immediately return to their home society.
Creating Resources
When societies use an action to create a new resource, there are broadly two scales of effort—
Basic
or
Epic
based on size or complexity.
Basic resources
are relatively easy to create. They are granted on a successful roll. A partial success may yield a
flawed resources
, which imposes disadvantage when used for their intended purpose, or
incomplete resources
which grans advantage on future attempts to refine or complete them.
Epic resources

are those demanding significant effort and would have transformative effects on the galaxy. They are so epic that they are not treated as “resources” in the usual sense, but rather become major elements or set pieces of the larger narrative that can have various ongoing narrative and mechanical impacts as decided by the GM. To complete these epic resources, societies must
commit 1/3rd of the total number of existing resources

. Committed resources can come from any Society and all resources that are committed are unusable for any other purpose and are, in practice, destroyed. A Society can only commit resources that are offered with consent by the controlling Community (offered during the Societal Phase). After an Epic resource project has begun, any Society can contribute additional resources during their turn at the dais during the Galactic Phase. This is done by the emissary and before taking an action.
Willpower Cards
During the Individual phase, players receive Willpower cards (explained in the Individual Phase).
Willpower

cards represent a sentiment rising within a community that has joined with the means to act upon it. Communities may wish to create something new, uphold the status quo, shift the power structure, or destroy that which does not work.

Willpower Cards are used by players during the Societal Phase. Players may choose to keep these cards private or share them publicly. Like Resources, Willpower cards can be traded with other Communities during the Societal Phase. Players can have up to three Willpower cards at a time, and must discard down to three as soon as they have more than three in their hand.
The Willpower Cards and their abilities include:

children.value: Play this card when another community in this society plays a Willpower card to
cancel the effect
of that card.
The Galactic Phase + Resolving Societal Actions
During the Galactic Phase, Societies announce their actions and roll dice to determine the success or failure of their actions.
Societies go in the order they arrived at the dais.
In turn, each Society announces the action that they attempt to take
. After a society has announced its action, they will answer any questions the Game Master may ask.
In turn, each Society rolls the appropriate dice
in order to resolve the action and discover the outcome.
The Game Master announces the results of the roll
, works with Emissaries to make any necessary decisions, and tells the story of the results. The Game Master should take no more than 3-minutes per Society maximum.
Resolving Societal Actions
Rolls
are the standard way a Society resolves an action.
The success or failure of a
Society’s action is decided by rolling one or multiple dice.
On a Fortune roll, you use the highest number rolled. If the highest number is:
1: Critical failure, something very bad will happen.
2, 3: Mixed Failure, you have failed your action.
4, 5: Mixed Success, you succeed at your action but at a cost or with an unexpected outcome.
6: Success, you succeed at your action and achieve your goal.
Multiple 6s: Critical success, you succeed at your action and achieve your goal with an additional positive outcome.
For a Roll, the number of dice you roll (your “dice pool”) is 1d6 per resource used in the action.
There are two other factors that impact the outcome of a roll during the Galactic Phase.
First is Risk Level.

The Risk Level always starts at 1 and might be increased by the GM, Willpower Cards, or in other ways. For every die rolled that is at or below the current Risk Level, one resource will be destroyed. The Emissary decides which resources are destroyed. For example:
If the risk level is 1, for every 1 rolled, one resource will be destroyed.
If the risk level is 3, and a player rolls 4 dice (6, 3, 2, 2) three resources are destroyed, alongside narrative success.
Second are “Advantage” and “Disadvantage.”

When taking actions, if a Society uses a resource and strategy that is particularly well suited to the situation, the GM may grant Advantage. Advantage allows a Society to reroll their lowest die if they choose, or if they are only rolling one die, roll twice and take the highest number.
If a Society uses a resource or strategy that is poorly suited to the situation or makes very little sense, they may be cursed with Disadvantage. When a Society has disadvantage they
must
remove the highest value among dice rolled, or if they are only rolling one die, roll twice and take the lower value.
Cross-Societal Aggression
A society may use their action to aggress against another society. This can take many forms:
A direct act of destruction against a specific resource.
A broad act of destruction against the populace.
An act of disinformation or sabotage.
And more!

Societal actions are resolved in the order that Societies arrive at the dais, which can have a major impact on the actions being taken. For example, if a society is successful at destroying another’s resources, they may well destroy a resource intended to be used by another society’s action later that round. In this case, the injured society will remove that die from their dice pool. If the destroyed resource was the primary resource for the action, the emissary can decide if they would like to forego taking an action or to take the action but with disadvantage alongside the removed die. The aggressed society may choose to retaliate when they deliberate on their next action.
Individual Phase

In the Individual Phase players develop and tell the story of one person who is part of the Community that they play as during the Societal Phase. Whereas the Societal Phase focuses on group decision-making and more traditional gameplay, the Individual phase focuses on individual autonomy and storytelling. During this phase, our lens zooms in to focus on the way that this one character relates to, responds to, and is impacted by the galactic and societal scale narrative.
The Individual Phase is broken down into three movements.
First, players are given a prompt that helps them develop and understand their character.
They are given one minute to think about this prompt on their own.
Ex. Imagine you are someone in the community you just represented in the last phase. What is this person’s role in your community?
Second, players are split into groups based on their Voice — Leaders to one area, People to another.

There, players are handed a willpower card from a deck at each station, and given an opportunity to mingle and converse with other people of their social class. Players may swap willpower cards with any other individual after interacting with them, if they so desire. Players may also choose to use this as a moment of quiet reflection.
Each area has the following willpower cards:
People
: Incite, Liberate, Surge
Leaders
: Influence, Manipulate, Usurp
Both:
Counter, Destroy, Empower, Resist, Seize
Creating a New Community

If a player’s Society is Lost by the beginning of an Individual Phase, they go to the Voice of the People area to create a new Community. This new community comes into play at the beginning of the next Societal phase.
Discard all resources and Willpower cards from your previous Community.
Take a blank Community sheet. Your new community will be a Voice of the People.
Create a new archetype that takes the form “[Adjective] [Noun]” ex. Rebellious Youth or Entrenched Dynasty,
Choose to receive either 2 new resources, 2 additional willpower cards, or one of each.
New resources are created using blank resource cards, and must be named immediately.
Willpower cards are drawn randomly from the Voice of the People Willpower deck.
Decide if their previous character joined this community or if they would like to create a new Individual.
Reflect with the facilitator on why this community is entering the spotlight at this moment in history.
The Universe Responds

During The Universe Responds, the Game Master reveals additional major plot developments, and may impact Societies and Communities with unexpected events. The GM may also announce any ongoing buffs or debuffs affecting Societies.
During the Universal Phase, if the GM is impacting a Society, the GM names the Communities impacted, and then the impacted Communities decide which of their resources are then impacted.
Ex. If a meteor hits a Society, the GM decides the impacted Community and the impacted Community picks which resource is transformed or destroyed.
Additionally, if a Voice of the Leaders is impacted, they may choose to instead impact a Voice of the People of their choosing.
The Generation Shifts

At the end of gameplay during every session, the Generation Shifts. During this phase the GM determines how many Generations pass between the current session and the following session, players make decisions about what their communities leave behind, and Societies work together to move their Story forward.
Between sessions the GMs gather the decisions made by Communities and Societies to update the starting Societies and Communities for the next day of play.
At the end of a session
Each player will receive a new community sheet to fill out.
First, from their remaining willpower cards, each player will pick the one they feel most captures their community’s hopes and desires for the future.
Then, on the new community sheet, they answer the prompt marked “At the end of a generation” on their chosen Willpower card, writing their answer in the space marked “Inherited Remembrance.”
If they have no Willpower cards remaining, they answer this question: “What is your community’s greatest regret from this generation?”

Then, the Game Master will roll 1d10 to determine how many generations pass, with a minimum of one full generation passing and a maximum of ten generations passing between sessions. Players write the number of generations passing on both the Generations Passing sheet and their new community sheet. While this is never equated directly to time, for storytelling purposes assume a generation is approximately 20 years.
Players roll 1d6 + the number of generations passing to determine how certain aspects of their Community change over time, using the three provided tables.
1. Community Archetype (written on the new Community sheet)

Finally, each Society works together to create a new story, containing the same three elements of “At first”, “but then”, and “and now.” For “At First” players copy what was written for their Society’s previous “and now.” For “But then” and “and now” the Societies create something new. This is recorded on the new society sheet.
Societies
In
Space Opera
, a society is composed of approximately 6 to 10 (ideally 8) players who work together to tell the story of how their society addresses the oncoming existential crisis.
The Parts of a Society
Every Society has the following Components:
A unique
Name
A
Home
which might be a planet, a moon, a caravan of starships, or something else.
An
Archetype
which is a simple, archetypical inspiration for building additional details of the society from.
The concepts:
The Mighty: Strength and Power
The Enterprise: Wealth and Commerce
The Grounded: Nature and Nurture
The Faithful: Hope and Spirit
The Scholars: Story and Tradition
The Aesthetic: Beauty and Truth
The Curious: Vision and Innovation
The Intrepid: Grit and Exploration
An
Ideal,
which is a simple phrase or sentence that exemplifies how that Archetype manifests in the players’ society.
A
Relationship History
which lays out one or two elements of the relationships between the other player Societies before gameplay begins.
A
Story

which is the broadly accepted internal history of the society and takes the form of, “At first ______. But then _____ And now, ______.” It is not important that every voice in your society believes in the story. It’s also not important that your Story be strictly true or historical. It is perfectly okay if two Societies have conflicting stories about each other.
For example, America’s Story might be
“At first, we were a British colony. But then, we fought for our freedom. And now, we’re the leaders of the free world.”
Your Story could be more mythological: At first, we were lost in the dark. But then, the prophets discovered the Sacred Mushrooms. And now, our Ecstatic Religion keeps us safe.
Communities
, which represent the groups of people currently in the “spotlight” of that society’s story.
Resources
, which represent the cultural footprint of the society’s communities, and enable the society to take actions.
Voices
Prompts
, which dictate the roles (Leader or People) that communities play in their society.
Name a community that is stuck in the past.
Name a community that honors tradition.
Name a community that disrupts the status quo.
Name a community that is persecuted.
Name a community that creates beauty.
Name a community that does the dirty work.
Name a community that holds power over others.
Name a community that is well respected by many.
Name a community that is innovative.
Name a community that causes trouble.
Name a community that brings people together.
Name a community that seeks the truth.
Name a community that sets the tone.
Name a community that needs protecting.
Name a community that has been around for a very long time.
Name a community that is newly formed.
Name a community that is secret.
Name a community that is constantly changing.
Name a community that has caused harm in the past.
Name a community that has been harmed in the past.
Society Archetypes

As Societies are being built, they pick one Fate from a group of three that are unique to that Society’s archetype. If a Society successfully completes their Fate, as decided by the GM, they become inspired and can add one additional d6 to one future roll of their choice. They also answer, collectively, the prompt for their Ideal.
The Fates and Ideals are:
The Mighty: Strength and Power
Ideal Prompt: What makes your society mighty?
We will claim what is ours
We will strengthen our bonds
We will hold the line
The Intrepid: Grit and Exploration
Ideal Prompt: How does your society explore the beyond?
We will forge a path
We will chart the unknown
We will risk safety for glory
The Scholars: Story and Tradition
Ideal Prompt: Through what tradition does your society remember the past?
We will bring history into the present
We will change the narrative
We will preserve something precious
The Enterprise: Wealth and Commerce
Ideal Prompt: How did your society acquire its wealth?
We will broker a new deal
We will turn a crisis into an opportunity
We will share the wealth
The Aesthetic: Beauty and Truth
Ideal Prompt: What does your society consider most beautiful?
We will create something beautiful
We will destroy something ugly
We will reveal the truth behind the facade
The Faithful: Hope and Spirit
Ideal Prompt: What does your society worship?
We will convert others to our ways
We will plunge into the unknown
We will keep our faith in the darkness
The Grounded: Nature and Nurture
Ideal Prompt: What natural aspect of your home does your society most treasure?
We will make something barren, verdant
We will root into the earth
We will engulf like vines
The Curious: Vision and Innovation
Ideal Prompt: How does your society innovate?
We will understand what was previously the unexplainable
We will reinvent what we have
We will make a technological breakthrough
A Guide for GMs
The Story of Space Opera
What kinds of stories are we interested in having players tell?

This question is pointing us to the kinds of situations we want players to encounter and grapple with during gameplay, and the answer informs the types of actions/reactions the GM takes to move the story, conflict, and situations in that direction
Groups of people encountering overwhelming odds.
Groups of people with diverse and potentially conflicting values, needs, and desires coming together to make hard decisions.
Groups of people whose relationships to one another change over time
Groups of people overcoming interpersonal conflict for the greater good
Groups of people having to reckon with their history/past
Groups of people impacting one another and reckoning and reconciling from those impacts.
What kinds of crises are we interested in exploring?
This question is pointing us towards what the existential crisis is, how the GM might design the campaign hook, and the types of new problems/conflicts that the GM might introduce.
Gray goo (assimilation parable, idea of a substance that is infinitely self-replicating and assimilating)
Stories of problems created by humanity
Mundane problems
External stressors
Eldritch
GMing in the Different Phases
The Game Master’s storytelling role varies pending the phase of gameplay.
In the Universal Phase
the GM’s primary contributions to the story include:
Setting the mood and tone.
Articulating and reiterating the current narrative stakes for the upcoming round.
Set-up or grow a clear conflict or challenge for the players to address.
Make the universe feel alive outside of the players’ existences.
Practically, the GM can answer the following prompts, like a script, to structure their storytelling.
What does the universe feel like right now?
Who are the major players or set pieces and their current status?
What is the most immediate obstacle or threat that each Society is facing?
What do the Societies stand to gain or lose at the end of the coming round?
Reiterate the most immediate obstacle or threat that each Society is facing.
In the Galactic Phase
the GM’s primary contributions to the story include:
Build a relationship with the emissary players to support their comfort and participation.
Clarify the action that the emissary is intending to take.
Support the emissary in fleshing out the details of their Society.
Clarify the context and consequences of the action that the Society has chosen to take.
Adjudicate the dice roll.
Narrate the results of the roll.
Facilitate any decision making the emissary must do.
Provide public and/or private information.
Practically, the GM can answer following prompts, like a script, to structure their storytelling.
Who is the player at the dias?
What is the action that the Society is taking?
Is there anything about the action, the intentions of the action, or the resources being used that needs to be clarified?
What are the mechanical impacts on the dice being rolled based on the narrative or other contextual mechanics? (Ex. You’ll get advantage because of X, the risk level will be set to X because of X)
The dice are rolled
Are the results of the roll good or bad?
Does the emissary need to make any hard mechanical choices?
What are the mechanical outcomes and what is the narrative outcome?
These should be communicated based on what creates the most dramatic tension and emotional impact.
Things the GM Can Do
This section is focused on creating clear prompts that support the GM’s creative storytelling to be in alignment with their Role.

Hard Reactions - Hard Reactions are reactions that cut right to the consequences of the intended action. The expected direct outcome from success or a negative outcome that happens immediately. Hard reactions should generally be tied to Failure, Success, and Critical Success

Soft Reactions - Soft Reactions leave room for the players to react. They may not fully succeed or fail on their attempted action and thus a new obstacle or opportunity may be presented to them. Soft Reactions should generally be tied to mixed successes and failures, or Failure and Success for larger or more complicated situations.
The GM can always:
Seed discord
Reveal true or misleading information
Create new problems
Expand the galaxy
Reveal the wonders and mysteries of space
Reveal a limited opportunity
Bring history into the present
Plant the seed of a future catastrophe
Destroy or change something that everyone relies on
Shine a spotlight on difference.
Speed up or slow down the passage of time
When the players succeed:
Gain a resource
Gain new information
Offer an opportunity
Describe what success looks like and choose between good options
Gain advantage
Transform a resource into something more desirable
Create a positive relationship with an NPC society
Remove dissent
Diffuse a threat
Generate a landmark
Create voices for the deck
When the players fail:
Destroy a resource
Exhaust a resource
Describe why something failed and make a hard choice
Gain a hardship
Gain disadvantage
Transform a resource into something less desirable
Create a negative relationship with an NPC society
Create dissent
Sever or transform a landmark
Destroy voices from the deck
Adjudicating Dice Rolls
The section below contains a list of narrative and mechanical outcomes that the GM might pick from when adjudicating the results of dice rolls.
Organized by Positive/Negative
Positive
Narrative
Gain helpful information
Offer an opportunity
Diffuse a threat
Create a positive relationship with an NPC society
Gain a narrative boon
Mechanical
Gain a resource
Transform a resource into something more desirable
Describe what success looks like and choose between good options
Gain advantage on a future roll
Gain inspiration
Negative
Narrative
Gain misleading information
Create a threat (imminent or long term)
Lose an opportunity
Create a negative relationship with an NPC society
Lose a narrative boon
Gain a narrative hardship
Mechanical
Destroy a resource
Exhaust a resource
Transform a resource into something less desirable
Describe why something failed and make a hard choice
Gain disadvantage on a future roll
Gain a hardship
Lose inspiration
Organized by Roll Results
1 - Should feel like a thrilling catastrophe and a sudden hardship.
Negative
Negatively transform a resource
Destroy a resource
Accelerate the crisis
Create a threat - immediate
Gain disadvantage on a future roll
Lose inspiration
Lose an opportunity
2 - Should feel like a total failure and an immediate threat of danger.
Negative
Describe why something failed and make a hard choice
Negatively transform a resource
Destroy a resource
Exhaust a resource
Create a threat - imminent
Accelerate the crisis
Lose a narrative boon
Create a negative relationship with an NPC society
Gain disadvantage on a future roll
Lose an opportunity
3 - Should feel like a failed mishap and a looming threat
Positive
Offer an opportunity
Gain helpful information
Gain advantage on a future roll connected to the failed action
Negative
Fail at creating a resource but gain advantage on a next attempt at gaining the resource
Negatively transform a resource
Destroy a resource
Exhaust a resource
Create a threat - looming
Lose a narrative boon
Gain disadvantage on a future roll
Create a negative relationship with an NPC society
Gain misleading information
Lose an opportunity
4 - Should feel like a near miss with a path forward
Positive
Gain a flawed resource on an action that was focused on gaining a resource, with an additional challenging outcome
Transform a resource into something more desirable on an action that was focused on gaining a resource, with an additional challenging outcome.
Gain advantage on a next attempt at gaining the resource on an action that was focused on gaining a resource
Gain helpful information
Offer an opportunity
Create a positive relationship with an NPC society
Negative
Negatively transform a resource
Gain misleading information
Create a threat - looming
Create a negative relationship with an NPC society
Exhaust a resource
5 - Should feel like a win, but not without its complications.
Positive
Gain a new resource on an action that wasn’t focused on gaining a resource
Gain a resource on an action that was focused on gaining a resource
Transform a resource into something more desirable
Gain helpful information
Offer an opportunity
Diffuse a threat
Create a positive relationship with an NPC society
Describe what success looks like and choose between good options
Gain advantage on a future roll
Gain inspiration
Negative
Gain misleading information
Create a threat - looming
Create a negative relationship with an NPC society
Exhaust a resource
6 - Should feel like a great success.
Positive
Gain a new resource on an action that wasn’t focused on gaining a resource
Gain a resource on an action that was focused on gaining a resource
Transform a resource into something more desirable
Gain a narrative boon
Critical Success - Should feel EPIC!
Any of the above positive options
A Note for GMs on “Information”
In Space Opera, information can arrive to players in two important and different forms that we identify as follows:
Information

- Information as something communicated to players in words. It is generally temporary and/or context specific. It likely only plays a meaningful role in the current generation. It makes sense as something that can grant advantages in a very particular context.
Knowledge

- Information as a gameplay Resource. It is longer-term, something that a community could form itself around, is wisdom that could be passed down for generations. Something you can “hang your hat on.”
On Pacing
Every round needs to feel like a new chapter in a book, not just the next line or paragraph.
The world needs to change drastically enough that an opportunity to act only exists for a single round.
The amount of time that passes between rounds is on the order of months and years, not days and weeks; Narrated and described through how the universe responds.
Player actions should be grand endeavors, not momentary attempts.
